dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We listen to the song as we pick up snapshots from an office of an early 70's music magazine: - Cigarettes are smoked indoors, everywhere. Smoke wafts over cubicles, everywhere. - Women wear mini-skirts. Really “mini” mini-skirts. - Music POSTERS and SIGNAGE line cubicle walls. Hendrix. Dylan. Simon and a Jew-fro’d Garfunkel. - A poster of a young RICHARD NIXON. Someone has drawn a MUSTACHE on Nixon’s face as well as a “SPEECH BUBBLE” which reads “I'm an asshole.” - We hone in on a SINGLE CIGARETTE. A hand places it in an ASHTRAY. The now-empty hand removes the needle from the record player (stopping the song).

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, it’s a hell of an album, Kid. People are gonna freak. The album goes into a SLEEVE and gets placed on a table. The album’s cover bears only a simple title: Danny Collins. The cigarette gets picked back up, and the “voice” takes his place behind a desk. His other hand picks up a DICTAPHONE.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (re: recording) This cool?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sure. He hits RECORD. A PACK OF CIGARETTES are held forward. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Smoke?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No thanks. The pack is pulled back REVEALING for the first time: OUR INTERVIEWER, GUY DELOACH (36). His style is of the day and his manner that of a hippie who thinks he knows everything about anything worth knowing. DeLoach leans back in his seat. He takes a long drag on his cigarette as he studies the YOUNG MAN opposite him.

dialogues.speaker: ON THIS YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Throughout, we see him only in FACELESS SNAPSHOTS. - Long hair, very much of the era. Open collared shirt. A hairless chest. - A single gold cross on the hairless chest. - Those few facial features we can make out are boyish, untouched by... well, anything.

dialogues.speaker: DELOACH
dialogues.text: Jesus H, you’re a baby. What are you, sixteen?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Twenty-one.

dialogues.speaker: DELOACH
dialogues.text: Jesus H. (beat, then) Well the album’s gonna be massive, Kid. Who got you there?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: DELOACH
dialogues.text: Your influences. Who do you dig? Who makes you hard?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) Oh, well, I--

dialogues.speaker: DELOACH
dialogues.text: Hold on. DeLoach picks up the recorder, speaks into it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DELOACH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: June 30th, 1971, Guy DeLoach with Danny Collins for Chime Mag. (then) More than anything it’s your writing. You write like fucking Lennon, man.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh, well, that’s... thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DELOACH
dialogues.text: He’s clearly an influence here, no?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I mean... I guess he’s the one who makes me the hardest? A beat. DeLoach LAUGHS, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DELOACH
dialogues.text: Jesus H. Well, you’re going to be huge, Kid. I know the real thing when I hear it and you’re it. Danny doesn’t say anything. DeLoach raises a brow.

dialogues.speaker: DELOACH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kid, look at me. I’ve been a star- maker and a star-fucker for a very long time, and I’m telling you: You. Are. Going. To. Be. Huge. Richer than richer, famous as shit, more women than you know what to do with. And I’m telling you this, and I’ve got to ask: why are you sitting there, staring at me, looking like that information scares the living shit out of you? Danny leans forward, full-frame for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Because it does.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: EXT. THE GREEK —- EVENING 3 The large marquee outside the famous theatre bears only four words: Danny Collins. Sold Out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign on the dressing room door reads: HEADLINER. In the distance we hear a dull, thumping ROAR. THUMP. THUMP. THUMP. A distant crowd awaits their star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HAND fingers a CROSS. The cross dangles from a chain, half buried in a patch of gray chest hair. The cross is removed, placed on a table. The cross OPENS, like a coffin, and dumps a line of COCAINE on a table. A NOSE comes into frame, snorts some.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE MIRROR
dialogues.text: Preparation for show time: - GRAY HAIR STRANDS are darkened with HAIR COLORER. - A GIRDLE is strapped over an undershirt. - PLATFORM SHOES are stepped into, providing an extra five inches of height.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From behind, we TRACK our hero as he marches through the bowels of the arena in his platform shoes - his steps are wobbly, not exactly in a straight line. He passes some GIGGLING GIRLS, nods at them. He passes a few “backstage” types, including a familiar ROADIE.

dialogues.speaker: ROADIE
dialogues.text: Break a leg, Danny. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (from behind) Just tell me whose. The Roadie LAUGHS as Danny moves on. The CHANTING CROWD grows closer.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE STAGE CURTAIN/DOOR
dialogues.text: From behind, we watch as he pauses. One deep breath. One crack of the neck, each way. Then: He gives a THUMBS UP to someone off to the side. The curtain/door opens as he steps out onto the stage in front of 20,000 adoring fans. Needless to say, they go completely bat-shit.

dialogues.speaker: ON STAGE
dialogues.text: We stay behind Danny as he strolls forward, takes the mic, and greets his fans.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming, Los Angeles. It’s good to be home. The crowd ROARS approval.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think you might know this one. Danny turns to his BAND, NODS, and... LIGHTS BLAST ON!!! Everywhere. The crowd ERUPTS. Our CAMERA SWEEPS over the crowd revealing, in full, DANNY COLLINS for the first time since he was twenty-one. He’s still a striking man, but the years have definitely left their mark. He wears an impeccably tailored but boldly colored outfit. And those platform shoes. Equal parts Rod Stewart and Neil Diamond. There are instruments everywhere... but Danny’s not playing any of them. This is over-the-top spectacle... but not caricature. The music, the act, it’s cheesy without being cartoony, campy without being completely void of melody. It's pretty clear that the stadium isn’t the only thing that has sold out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Danny has clearly led off with his biggest hit, akin to Sweet Caroline (equally catchy, almost as good). Sweet Caroline is a good reference actually, mainly because from the first note (and especially the chorus), the audience is SINGING ALONG in a call and response fashion (TWO VIDEO SCREENS even cue the audience to sing their part with bouncing-ball karaoke-esque prompts). The CROWD (older) eats it all up. A WOMAN sings his chorus “Hey, Baby Doll” while also wearing a “Hey, Baby Doll” T-shirt. ANOTHER WOMAN holds up a sign that reads “This Granny Loves Danny.”

dialogues.speaker: ON DANNY
dialogues.text: During the song he mingles with women in the front row - he kisses one woman’s hand, blows a kiss to another. He makes a show out of giving one woman his SCARF. Danny takes in...

dialogues.speaker: THE CROWD
dialogues.text: AN OLDER COUPLE, arm and arm, SING the response part of the song back at him. They’re singing way too hard. THREE OLDER WOMEN sit quietly in their front row seats, eating RED VINES and mouthing words along, lifeless. A GROUP OF YOUNG PEOPLE sings along with energy... but they’re LAUGHING. They’re not laughing with Danny.

dialogues.speaker: ON DANNY
dialogues.text: He’s seen it all a thousand times. It no longer fazes him. He pivots with a little shimmy, keeps performing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny SLUMPS in a chair, his dressing room has transformed into the site of an after-party. Danny fingers an expensive scotch (and his cross) as he does his best to stay awake. TIM, a thirty-something, comes into view through Danny’s scotch glass.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Mr. Collins, do you think I could bother you for a quick picture? (before Danny can answer ) Just real quick, my mom will die-- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: OFF TO THE SIDE
dialogues.text: A MAN in an expensive suit drinks a BOTTLE OF WATER, watches. This is FRANK GRUBMAN (60's). (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (picture accomplished) Awesome, I'll tweet this to you.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Awesome. Tim, the cell-phone-photo-seeker, takes his leave. Frank shakes his head, walks over to Danny.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It was a good show, Kid.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Inspired. Frank tilts his head, takes Danny in.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hey, Sylvia Plath? You okay?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m fine. Birthday blues or some shit I guess. That’s all Frank needs to hear. He stands.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Alright everyone, sorry but my guy needs a little rest. No one really listens.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: LISTEN UP YOU LEECHES, IT’S TIME

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Frank, let ‘em be--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No, Danny, I can name three people in this room and that’s about three more than you can. (to room)

dialogues.speaker: DID I STAMMER, I SAID GET THE FUCK
dialogues.text: out! The mumbling crowd begins dispersing. Once they’re gone, Danny and Frank sit in silence for a moment. Then:

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Birthday’s not till tomorrow, Kid. Got a few hours till the state mandated depression has to set in. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You see the Golden Girls sitting in the front row? Eating liquorice the entire time?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Can’t choose your fans, Danny.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Three of them. Each of them older than the next. Made one pack of liquorice last the entire show. Just sat there gumming it for two hours. This hangs there. Frank tries cheering him up.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: New billboard went up on Sunset for the album. You should check it out on the way home. Danny nods, staring off into space. Frank STANDS.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alright, enough of this crap. It's your birthday tomorrow, that’s your big problem? Pregnant women in Africa, feeding half their village from their titties... those ladies have problems. Not you. Danny smiles weakly.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No, I know. You're right.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: ‘Course I’m right, I’m always right. So go home to your stunning half-your-age fiancé who’s throwing you the massive surprise party tomorrow that I didn’t just tell you about. Then come tell me and the sore tittied African ladies about all your problems.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Okay. He stands, goes to exit. Frank’s voice stops him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It was a good show, Kid. Really. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Danny turns, about to say something, then thinks better of it. He simply replies:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. CUE SONG: Working Class Hero (TBD) by John Lennon. I/E. DANNY’S MERCEDES - LATER 10 It's a preposterous car for anyone... let alone a man in his sixties. Silver on the outside, leather everywhere on the inside, it’s a spaceship on wheels. Inside: Danny, exhausted, does everything he can to keep his eyes from closing as he navigates Los Angeles traffic. INT. DANNY’S MERCEDES - LATER 11 Danny eases the car up to the GATE of a MANSION. He tries using his “clicker.” It doesn’t work. He SIGHS, TOOTS the horn. In the booth of the guardhouse stands a DOORMAN, currently talking on a HOUSE PHONE. This is MARTY (40's). Marty holds up a finger ("Be with you in a second”). Danny parks, waits. After a beat, Marty hangs up and approaches. Danny SIGHS, lowers the window.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: We gotta get that fixed for you, Mr. Collins. Good show tonight?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It was, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Calling it early? No after-party?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Little tired. Just looking to hit the sack so... He motions at the gate. Marty doesn’t take the hint.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: What’d you open with tonight?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Same as always. (then) (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I really gotta hit the sheets, Kid. Marty nods.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: Have a good night, Mr. Collins. Marty walks toward the gate, hits a BUTTON. It opens, revealing SHANGRI-LA. Is this a home or a “Four Seasons”? Danny literally has to cross a “bridge” to get to his home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny ENTERS the house.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I’m home! No response. Danny heads toward the tall staircase, looks at it, SIGHS - then turns around and gets in... An ELEVATOR, which carries him upwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bed fit for a king. Fireplace. Huge flat-screen.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Babe! ?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m in the shower! Danny walks into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A female figure (masked by steam) showers. The shower is roughly the size of Rhode Island. Danny walks past the shower.

dialogues.speaker: SHOWERING WOMAN
dialogues.text: Hey! Sorry I missed the show.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You've seen it before. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Danny heads into his ADJACENT WALK-IN CLOSET (filled to the brim with high-end men’s clothing in bold patterns) and begins hanging his jacket. He calls back.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’d you do tonight?

dialogues.speaker: SHOWERING WOMAN
dialogues.text: Just busywork around here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ll.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Always doing busywork.

dialogues.speaker: SHOWERING WOMAN
dialogues.text: It's a big house. Running it keeps a girl busy. (then) I‘1ll be out in a minute. I’m just finishing shaving.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Okay. (then, realizing) Oh, Hon? Danny turns back toward the shower. The door to the shower opens, revealing: SOPHIE (31). She’s Danny’s fiancé. She’s very young, very hot, and very naked. And she’s currently shaving her pubic hair with a disposable pink razor (shaving cream covers the region).

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus, Sophie.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: What? He shakes his head, thrown by the sight, and turns to go. Then he stops, remembering:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah: the kid out front, can you do something about him? I don’t need a half hour of chitchat every time I pull into my house.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: He’s just trying to impress you.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, he’s failing. (then) Okay, I’m gonna go write.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Okay, Baby. (then, realizing) Wait, write who?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Just... Sophie, please watch what you’re doing, you’re going to maim yourself. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (then) Don’t wait up, alright? He EXITS the bathroom. She calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Seriously, Baby! Who are you writing? No reply. Sophie SHRUGS, continues her grooming. INT. DANNY’S HOME STUDIO - LATER 16 It's a great space. A PIANO sits dead center. It’s obvious, however, that the room is not used often.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE WALLS
dialogues.text: Covered in PLATINUM ALBUMS and framed copies of Danny’s records. The cover art on the albums tells a story - from that first SIMPLE ALBUM to the “look” he’s developed over the past decade or two (same typeface, posing, etc.). Danny ENTERS the room, looks around, and spots what he’s looking for: a BOX OF EMBOSSED STATIONARY PAPER. He carefully opens the box. Grabs a sheet. It’s blank. They're all blank. He looks until he finds... a fancy MONTBLANC-esque pen. He takes it out, looks at it, sits at the piano and takes his time perfectly setting the pen and paper into “writing position.” Danny begins playing a simple melody. A few chords. The beginning of something simple, melodic, and gentle. He pauses, puts on his glasses. Thinks for a beat, then... smiles. He grabs his pen and, just then... Catches sight of himself in the studio mirror:

dialogues.speaker: ON HIS REFLECTION
dialogues.text: An old man in a silly suit, wearing platform shoes and reading glasses, trying to write something original after what's clearly been a long hiatus from just that.

dialogues.speaker: ON DANNY
dialogues.text: Realizing. He stops, unwilling to go further. You can see it in his eyes. What’s the point? He puts down the pen, leans back, and closes his eyes. He falls asleep sitting up.  17 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny pulls up to the house. Sophie holds leftovers in her lap; she’s dressed in something super revealing. Danny wears something that makes him look like a mid-60's pimp. You can imagine the looks they got at the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Good birthday brunch, Baby?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (nodding) Good birthday brunch. She kisses his cheek. He smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So how many people are inside?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Dammit! Fucking Frank! Danny SIGHS.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Honey: you can’t surprise a man my age. You want to give me a heart attack or something? She motions at her ring finger.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Not until it’s legal.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Funny.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Uch, I’m so pissed at him! Sophie reaches into her purse, pours a line of coke on the dash, bends forward and does some.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want? Danny SIGHS.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You are trying to kill me. He accepts some, does it quickly, moves for the car door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sweetheart?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Fix your dress. Her right breast is hanging out of the low-cut dress. Danny EXITS the car.

dialogues.speaker: FROM OUTSIDE THE CAR
dialogues.text: Danny heads toward the house. We hold there a beat, then Sophie exits the car and scampers after him (attempting to fix her dress as she scampers).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ENTER the house to a huge:

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Surprise! The main living area is full of GUESTS. Danny feigns shock, looks to Frank, front and center. Frank motions to him: “act surprised.”

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No way! Are you kidding me!? (to Sophie) You did this? But Sophie’s already hopped up, barely listening, rubbing her nose and sniffling. Danny covers her behavior by hugging her. The CROWD AWWWWES.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (putting on a show) Don’t you all know you don’t surprise a man my age? You could have given me a heart attack! Everyone LAUGHS. Someone CUES Danny’s MOST FAMOUS SONG (the one we saw him open the concert with).

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think I know this one! LAUGHTER. Danny couldn’t be more miserable, but he’s had decades of experience performing. And boy, can he perform. As WELL-WISHERS descend on Danny we launch:  19 14~A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PARTY MONTAGE (CUE SONG TBD: John Lennon’s “Whatever Gets You Through The Night”). (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Danny goes through the motions in snapshots. - He watches OLDER MEN ogle YOUNGER WOMEN frolicking in his pool. - He and Frank watch as TWO YOUNG GUESTS ransack his wine cellar. - He OPENS gifts, relishes in receiving a bottle of SCOTCH with a ribbon around it. - He DOES COKE in the bathroom, alone. - He watches two IDIOTS pour vodka/white wine in his Koi pond. - At one point, he spots Sophie chatting with Marty outside (the doorman). He watches as she hands him some CASH. - He receives the gift of a SCARF from a FAMOUS FRIEND. He places it in a pile of identical boxes (everyone has gotten him scarves). - By the time evening descends on the party, we pull away from the festivities, ending on Danny’s familiar shoes. But this time, the shoes are empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party has pretty much cleared out, day has turned into night. Danny (socks, no shoes) and Frank (his Manager, we met him before) sit on Danny’s luxurious roof deck. Danny holds his recently gifted bottle of scotch (still with ribbon, now half empty). Opposite them, Sophie is passed out on a love seat. As usual, she’s hanging out everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: She’s like a young Jackie 0. Danny CHUCKLES, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I look absurd with her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes, you do. A beat. She begins to snore, drunkenly.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: We have to make her sign a prenup, don’t we? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Yes, we do. Another beat.

dialogues.speaker: 15A.
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I’m way too old to be putting this much shit up my nose.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes, you are.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Jesus, don’t give me all the good stuff at once, Frank. You’re really earning that ten percent tonight, Pal.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What do you want me to say? No, Danny, you look totally normal standing next to a coked up teenager who can’t keep her nipples covered for more than five minutes. Prenup? Who needs a prenup? I mean sure, you’ve been through three wives already, but this one really seems like the real deal. Oh look, I can see her vagina again! Danny smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Cute.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thank you, I try. Frank STANDS.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, so... I got you a birthday present and it cost me a fortune so do me a favor and upside down the frown for five minutes, huh? Frank smiles, bends, and picks up a wrapped GIFT. Danny starts unwrapping. Frank explains, excitedly:

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know how fanatical you are about Lennon, so I started futzing around on the internet. Ebay, Lennon memorabilia, that kind of stuff. Wrapping paper is off. Danny starts removing ribbons. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I get in touch with this one guy, a collector, say I’m looking to get you something special. Frank takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Holy shit, I’ve been holding this in for three months now! (then) Danny, wait, hold on. Danny stops opening the gift.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You remember doing an interview, when you were a kid? Something called Chime Magazine? Fella named DeLoach?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (confused) Yeah. Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you’d said to the guy - you mentioned Lennon, doesn’t matter. Point is: Lennon read it! And he wrote you a letter! Danny lowers the box, confused.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What? Frank, what the hell are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: John Lennon wrote you a letter, Pal! In 1971. He sent it to you at the magazine, care of this DeLoach guy. DeLoach smells money - handwritten letter from John Lennon and all - so he holds onto it, never tells you. DeLoach died, he’s not the point. The point is he sold the letter to a collector. Can you believe this shit?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I’m not following this, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Open the box, just open it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Danny does, slowly. Frank has had the letter framed and Matted, beautifully.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE LETTER
dialogues.text: It’s small, handwritten. Very personalized.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A handwritten letter to you from John Lennon, written in 1971. Can you fucking believe it? Read it! Danny is still processing. He reads, out loud, slowly:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Dear Danny Collins. Yoko and I read your interview. Being rich and famous doesn't change the way you think. It doesn't corrupt your art. Only you can do that. So what do you think about that, Danny Collins? Stay true to your music. Stay true to yourself. The rest will follow. My phone number is below. Call me, we can discuss this. We can help. Love, John.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Crazy, right!? I’ve been sitting on this thing for months... As Frank continues rambling excitedly, we PUSH in...

dialogues.speaker: ON DANNY
dialogues.text: He’s just staring at the letter. Reading it, over and over. His world has clearly just rotated on its axis. A letter from your hero, meant to be delivered to you when you were twenty-one. Warning you of all the things you wound up doing and now regret. Forty years too late. Can you imagine? CUE SONG: Imagine (TBD) written by John Lennon. Everything SLOWS as Danny looks around the deck. The imagery conflicts with the beautiful song: his fiancé, belching and half-conscious. The hangers-on passed out everywhere. His preposterously lavish mansion. Sad, horrific, irony. The song carries into...  21 22 23 24

dialogues.speaker: A25
dialogues.text: 25 19. INT. DANNY’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 21 Danny lies there holding the letter, still staring at it. It’s 5:45 AM and he hasn’t slept. He’s slowly unraveling. He gets up, whispers to Sophie:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I’ll be back late. She waves a hung-over arm at him. INT. DANNY’S MERCEDES - EARLY MORNING 22 Danny drives through Los Angeles. The Sunset Strip, home to the Roxy, the Whisky. Have you ever driven down Sunset when there’s not a soul in sight? It’s surreal. The whole time the letter sits next to Danny, on the passenger seat. Haunting him. Danny pulls the car over. EXITS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny walks to the curb. Looks up. Just stares. We cut WIDE, revealing what he’s staring at: HIS GIANT BILLBOARD. Danny stands in front of it, miniscule in comparison, taking in the ridiculous picture of himself winking at/pointing at camera - the oversized portrait a symbol of every bad decision he’s ever made. And that does it... Slowly... ever so slowly: a smile creeps over his face. He cracks his neck, coming to terms with a decision, and: He gets back in the car and races off. Full speed now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mercedes turns toward the gate. But then... the car keeps going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny pops out from behind the “bridge.” He’s entered his own property, unseen. He scampers across the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny strides into the house. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I’m home! We hear frantic FOOTSTEPS in the distance. Danny smiles, marches toward the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophie lies in bed, confused and a little frazzled. Danny strides past her.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I thought you were coming home late.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Change of plans. Danny heads through the bathroom into the walk-in closet. He takes out a SUITCASE, begins packing. Sophie ENTERS.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Packing.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m going away. (then) Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Whoever you were just in bed with, where is he hiding? (then) You know what, I‘’1l just ship everything. He grabs A SMALL BAG, exits the closet. Begins looking around the bathroom, grabbing toiletries.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Danny-—

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Honey, I didn’t pull in, so the guy outside couldn’t call you and stall me. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not mad, I promise, I just don’t want to open a closet and have a strange man jump out and scare the shit out of me. He’s not in the closet, is he?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (relenting) No.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Good. Danny RE-ENTERS the BEDROOM, calls out:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can come out! I promise I’m not mad!

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Jesus. (loudly) Just come out. It’s okay. A YOUNG HANDSOME MAN in TIGHTY-WHITIES comes out from under the bed. Danny smiles, continues throwing crap in his small bag.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (to the guy) You must be busywork.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Judd.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I’1l call you busywork. She’s always doing busywork. Now I understand.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (apologetic) Danny.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Sweetie, I could not be less mad. I had fun, did you have fun?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Good. I’m glad. You stay. Keep the house for a while. You and Busywork here. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Be young, have fun, I need my address book, there’s an address I need in my address book. Ah, here it is. Danny leans in toward Sophie, kisses her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I would have made you sign a prenup anyway. You’re not missing out on any big money if that makes you feel better.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I guess it does a little.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I’m glad. Danny holds his hand out toward Judd. They shake.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Busywork, take care of her.

dialogues.speaker: JUDD
dialogues.text: My parents had their first dance to one of your songs, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well that’s fucked up in all kinds of ways now, isn’t it? (then) Okay, adios Kids. He grabs his BAG and EXITS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny EXITS the house, a skip in his step. He heads across his bridge as he talks on his CELL PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hey, have the plane ready. To New Jersey. (then) Yes, New Jersey. (then) Car, too. You know what I like. But how ‘bout a red one? (then) Yes, red. I’m changing shit up. Danny gets in his car and takes off. We can hear his LAUGHTER all the way down the street. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CUE SONG: Hold On (TBD) written by John Lennon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny steps off the PRIVATE JET and heads down a set of stairs as a... RED MERCEDES (identical car, different color) pulls up next to the bottom of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mercedes pulls up in front of this ordinary Hilton. The rest of the lot is littered with Toyotas and Fords.

dialogues.speaker: ON A VALET KID, (22)
dialogues.text: Standing there, bored. He sees the Mercedes approach.

dialogues.speaker: VALET KID
dialogues.text: (re: car) Holy shit. The car pulls to a stop. Danny steps out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: VALET KID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (re: Danny Collins) Holy shit! The kid runs forward.

dialogues.speaker: VALET KID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Welcome to the Hilton, Danny Collins... Mr. Collins... (trying again) Welcome to the Hilton, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It's good to be at the Hilton, young man. And call me Danny. What should I call you?

dialogues.speaker: VALET KID
dialogues.text: Nicky Ernst.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Nicky Ernst, it’s an absolute pleasure. You have a wonderful face. Here, have a hundred dollars. He hands Nicky a HUNDRED. Nicky masks his excitement. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NICKY
dialogues.text: So. Mr... Danny... will you be staying with us, or just joining us for lunch today?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Nicky: I’m going to be staying with you, I’m going to be joining you for lunch, I’m going to be taking advantage of all the amenities the Woodcliff Lake Hilton has to offer... Nicky, I can’t help but notice that you’re drooling on my car.

dialogues.speaker: NICKY
dialogues.text: Sorry. It’s just so... awesome.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You're welcome to use it whenever you want, take your girl out for a spin. You have a girl?

dialogues.speaker: NICKY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You will if you take her out for a spin in this car.

dialogues.speaker: NICKY
dialogues.text: Wait, seriously? Danny is already walking away.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (calling back) Bag goes to my room, Nicky. Car goes in a garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny walks in. It could be any hotel, in any city. A LOBBY. A lobby RESTAURANT. A lobby BAR. That’s it. A SIGN reads: “WELCOME GREATER NJ DENTAL ASSOCIATION.” There’s a DISPLAY front and center, full of “dental” swag. Danny walks to the front desk. A PRETTY YOUNG GIRL (23) works on the computer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GIRL
dialogues.text: (not looking, bored) Welcome to the Hilton, do you have a reservation? 24A. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She SIGHS, 25.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I do not have a reservation, but I’m hoping that won’t be a deal- breaker because I am rapidly falling in love with this Hilton. looks up.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GIRL
dialogues.text: Holy shit!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I get that a lot. What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GIRL
dialogues.text: Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Jamie, I’m Danny.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I know who you are.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What about Nicky out front? Do you know who he is?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: The valet guy?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Nicky Ernst. Ask him to take you for a ride in my car, you'll fall in love. (then) Look at you! Another fantastic young face. What an amazing place this Woodcliff Lake Hilton is. Why are your faces so fantastic and young?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: We're all college kids I guess, off for summer or just graduated.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Ah. That must be it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: How long will you be staying with us, Mr. Collins? Danny pulls out his ADDRESS BOOK from his suit pocket. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Jamie, my GPS tells me that we’re not far from a Hillsdale, New Jersey. Now tell me: is my GPS lying to me or giving me the straight shit?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Straight shit. You’re five minutes away.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well, then I will be staying indefinitely. Jamie smiles, a little confused.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Okay. I'11 give you the Honeymoon Suite, it’s our nicest room... only I don’t know how to do an indefinite reservation.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Don’t need a honeymoon suite. Just a regular, everyday room. Jamie turns toward the back, yells out.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: 5 (calling out) lary?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: If someone else with a wonderful face comes out, I don’t know if I‘ll be able to handle it. MARY SINCLAIR emerges from the BACK OFFICE. She's amazing looking, great smile... classically beautiful without trying.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, I officially can’t handle it. Jamie darts over towards Mary, WHISPERS loudly.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Look who it is!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (calmly) I see. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (rapid-fire whisper) He wants to stay indefinitely. I was going to give him the Honeymoon Suite but--

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (loudly) He didn’t want the Honeymoon Suite. Mary and Jamie turn toward him, synchronized.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s not my honeymoon and I’m not very sweet. Regular room will do just fine. Mary approaches. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And what college do you go to young lady?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Ha.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Ha.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You’re staying indefinitely? Here?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Huge fan of this Hilton. (then) Are you married, Mary?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Are you currently betrothed?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Good. Dinner?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You’re asking me to dinner? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I think so. Jamie, I asked her to dinner, didn’t I?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (excited) You did.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, are you on drugs?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Currently or in general?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Currently.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No. (then) Dinner?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I’m going to have to decline.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Not a fan of mine?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Currently or in general?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: In general.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: God, we have a great patter, don’t we!? Jamie, can you follow any of this?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: (giggling, excited) No! Mary smiles, shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I’‘1l check you in.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: While you check me in, I’1l check you out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Mary goes back to the computer. Despite herself: she can’t help but smile, just a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could be any hotel room in the world. A bed, a small desk, a love seat. That’s it. Danny takes it in, thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny oversees as FOUR LARGE MEN try to figure out how to move a BABY GRAND PIANO through the door to his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything has been moved to make room for the massive piano, which dwarfs everything else.

dialogues.speaker: ON DANNY
dialogues.text: Taking it in. He may as well be taking in the Sistine Chapel. He digs into his bag, and pulls out the framed LENNON LETTER. Sets it up on his nightstand. He takes in his strange new home and smiles:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PATRONS talk, whisper, point at...

dialogues.speaker: THE OTHER SIDE OF THE ROOM
dialogues.text: Where Danny sits at the bar. He’s wearing a customary over-the-top suit and is drinking scotch. He’s writing furiously. It’s important to note that he’s finally able to write using hotel stationary and an ordinary hotel pen, aS opposed to his Montblanc and embossed stationary. ON THE PAD: the beginnings of a lyric. Stuff about the seasons - “spring” and “fall.” Just a start.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Danny? Danny turns. Frank stands there. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Frank! Danny stands, envelopes Frank in a surprising BEAR HUG.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sit, sit. Thanks for coming.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Got on the first flight out.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Thanks. Have you been here before?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The bar at the Woodcliff Lake, New Jersey Hilton? (then, obviously) No. Frank sits. He’s obviously concerned.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I spoke to Sophie. She said you--

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I did. (then, calling out) Barkeep? An ice water for this handsome young man, por favor? Danny turns toward Frank, serious.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Frank, I’ve decided to make some big changes in my life. Some of them may come as a bit of a shock, some of them may even affect you financially. Frank puts his hand on Danny’s knee.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m here as your friend, Danny. Not as your manager.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Actually, I need you to be here as my manager for a moment. (then) I want you to cancel the rest of my tour.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m sorry? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Don’t be sorry, I’m not sorry. I’m done, Frank. (then) Oh, I’1l also need you to call Bill, tell him to sell all my stock, all the houses. I want no debt, no risk. So help me God I will never be forced to sing those songs again. Oh, wait, tell Bill not to sell the LA house yet. I’m going to let Sophie and the kid she was cheating on me with stay there--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Danny, stop! You’re spiraling. Are you on something? What did you take?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Nothing, I promise. Actually, I’m done with that shit too. No more drinking, no more drugs--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You’re drinking right now, Danny.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: True. Okay, forget what I said about the drinking. I’m not running for Pope, right?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: This is because of Sophie?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Sophie? No! Jesus, Frank, give me a little credit. Danny puts down his drink. Changes tone.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What if I had gotten the letter when I was supposed to, Frank? He was my hero. I would have called him. (then) Maybe my life would have turned out different.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You’re too hard on yourself, Kid. Always have been. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I haven’t written a song in thirty years, Frank. I’m a fucking joke. I’m a court jester with a microphone. (then) I was the real thing once, Frank. One album. My songs didn’t sell so they handed me theirs and I sang them. I gave up, Frank. Frank leans forward, concerned. Gently:

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You’re having a breakdown, Danny.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Hate to tell you, Buddy, but I’ve been breaking down for forty years. I’m broken. Ain’t nothing left to break. (beat, then) I’m sixty-four, Frank. I’ve been abusing my body for the better parts of four decades. If I’m gonna find any kind of redemption, I can’t waste anymore time. A beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Why New Jersey?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: One shock at a time, Frank. Frank nods, sips his water.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: A sixty-something man starts canceling tours, people start wondering. I’m talking to you as your manager, Danny.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Actually, I need you to be my friend again now. Frank nods, sits there for a beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’ll cancel the tour. Danny nods back, clinks his scotch against Frank’s water. They turn back toward the bar in unison. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: After a beat, from behind, Frank puts his hand on Danny’s shoulder. There’s nothing left to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny walks through the lobby, a spring in his step. His outfit/suit is typically bold. He stops at the front desk. Jamie and Mary are there.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Jamie, have you talked to Nicky Ernst about taking that ride yet?

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Not yet, Mr. Collins. He turns to Mary.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Dinner at seven? I’1ll meet you... He points five feet away.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Still gonna have to pass.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Mary, you keep passing, I'll keep making passes, we’ll see who gives up first, sound good?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Have a nice day, Mr. Collins.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Big day for me. Meeting someone for the first time. How do I look?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Honestly?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: If this relationship is going to go the distance, Mary, I think we should always be honest with one another.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You look ridiculous. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Nah, I look sharp. See you at seven.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No you won't.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: And round and round we go. (turning) Jamie, don’t forget about Nicky Ernst. Wonderful young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny steps outside, Nicky waits with his car.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Nicky my boy!

dialogues.speaker: NICKY
dialogues.text: She’s ready for you, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: The girl at the front desk, she won't stop talking about you, Nicky. You should ask her out.

dialogues.speaker: NICKY
dialogues.text: (stunned) Jamie?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That’s the one. Don’t go after Mary, Mary's mine. Danny gets in the car, rips out of the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very modest HOUSE, in a very modest NEIGHBORHOOD. This is “real world” central. TOYS are scattered around the lawn. It could not be more ordinary. And up to this house pulls a gleaming, red Mercedes. Driven by Danny Collins. National superstar. Wearing, what can best be described, as a zoot suit. As he strides across the lawn, stepping over a tricycle, a SUBURBAN DAD raking leaves does a double take.  38 EXT. FRONT DOOR —- CONTINUOUS Danny RINGS the bell. No sound. He rings again. Nothing. He RAPS on it. He holds a BROWN BAG. Footsteps from inside. Danny braces himself. The OPENS, revealing: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Nobody.

dialogues.speaker: CHILD'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello. Danny looks downward at: A LITTLE GIRL (7). This is HOPE, Danny’s granddaughter. Needless to say, Hope is pretty fucking cute.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hope, you are not to open that door for strangers!

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: He’s not a stranger. We saw him on TV. Mom, come here, it’s the guy we saw on TV. Mom, Mom--

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What? Hope’s mother arrives. This is SAMANTHA (30's). Samantha is pretty and pregnant. She’s a study in contrasts: tough but emotional, sexy but a little tomboyish, and - at the moment - calm but completely thrown by the sight of Danny Collins on her front doorstep.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Whoa.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: Told you. I told you. You didn’t listen but I tried to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Hi, I’m Danny.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: We know who you are.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: (imitating) Yeah! We know who you are!

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: (to Hope) Settle, Baby. Inside voices, okay? Samantha and Hope look back up at Danny.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: I don’t really know who you are. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Danny bends down, takes in Hope for the first time. He touches her face, gentle. Up above them, Samantha doesn’t move, unsure what to do. Danny stands back up, offers forth his BROWN BAG.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I was unsure of what was appropriate to bring...

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: He’s at work.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: So I brought bagels.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Wow. Okay. This is weird. I guess... come in? Danny follows them into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see FAMILY PICTURES on the fridge. Child drawings. A dirty pan in the sink. There are no granite tops here. It's warm, but tight. Danny, Sam, and Hope sit in the small kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: How did you--

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I hired someone to track him down years ago. Never got up the nerve until now. Danny puts the bagels on the table.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: I want a bagel, can I have a bagel Mommy ! ? As Samantha starts cream-cheesing a bagel for Hope, she looks at Danny.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Wow. I mean... wow on so many levels.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: Too much cream cheese Mommy-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Samantha realizes what she’s doing. 36A. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Sorry, Baby.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How far along are you?

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Six months.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Boy or girl, do you know?

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Boy.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: A boy. Wow.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: On so many levels. (beat, then) I have to call him.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Of course. She walks over to the counter, keeping an eye on Danny.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So... Hope, what grade are you in?

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: I just finished the first grade. My teacher is named Mrs. Williams. Her aunt died last week so we had a substitute. He had a mustache. Why are you on TV?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Because I’m a singer.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: Are you a good singer?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No, not really.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: I didn’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Hope!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (smiling) Why didn’t you think so? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: Because when you were on the TV, Daddy said “Shut it off, Samantha,” and Mommy turned it off really fast, and then Mommy said, “Tom?” and Daddy said, “No” and that was that. Samantha starts to say something, but then starts talking into the phone (he’s gotten on the line). As she talks, she steps out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Hey, so... your fa... Danny Collins just showed up at the house. (long beat) Uh-huh. I know. Having bagels in the kitchen with Hope. (beat) What was I supposed... (beat) Yes. Okay. She hangs up, returns into the kitchen, puts on a big fake smile, and announces:

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s coming home.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: Yay! Danny looks at Samantha. She SHRUGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope is watching television, completely absorbed. Danny and Samantha sit awkwardly on the couch behind her, watching her watch the television.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: I have so many questions.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Ask away.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: I can’t think of any of them now. Hope SCREAMS at the TV.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hope? Calm, okay? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Danny looks at Hope... currently running around in small circles, dancing. It’s partially adorable, partially manic.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She seems... energetic.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Severely hyperactive. Learning issues, behavioral stuff, we do the best we can but it’s a battle-- why are you here? The question’s delivery catches Danny by surprise.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I’m making some changes.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: It’s a little late for that, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Maybe. I hope not. Samantha leans back, thinks for a moment. Then:

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: My husband is the best man I’ve ever met. Solid. Kind. Funny. We've had one fight. Twelve years, one serious fight. Two years ago, I got backstage passes to one of your shows, thought it was time he should... at least meet you. (then) He disagreed. He disagreed strongly.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: So this isn’t going to be pretty?

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: No. I wouldn't imagine it will be.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well, if you could help grease the wheels at all--

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Mr. Collins, my parents are dead. His mom is too. I'd like my daughter to know her one remaining grandparent, I would. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’d like my husband to know his father. And I’1l admit to being a little star-struck by you. But in a minute, my husband is going to walk through that door. And when he does, I’m confident that this will be the last time I ever see you. And despite your celebrity, and despite what I want for my family, I will not try and stop that. You did this to yourself. Shame on you. Danny NODS, understanding.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That was good.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: (emotional) I’ve been practicing it in my head since you gave me the bagels. Danny smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He married well.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m pretty great. You see? You really missed out. And just then: the FRONT DOOR opens. There stands TOM (40). Handsome. He wears boots, work clothes, clearly fresh off a construction job. He could not be dressed less like the man currently sitting on his couch.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: Daddy! Daddy! Tom’s eyes remain fixed on Danny as he hugs Hope (who is becoming overwhelmed by all the excitement).

dialogues.speaker: HOPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (hyper ) Look who it is! It’s the man from TV! It’s the man from the TV that we saw singing, and Mommy said “whoa” and he brought bagels--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hope, easy.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: He brought bagels and Mommy called you and now you’re home early and-- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (calmly) Hope? She looks up at him. Tom begins an adorable father- daughter calming ritual; the whole time never breaking his “if looks could kill” stare at Danny.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your favorite flower is a--

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: Rose!

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: To smell it you breathe through your... She takes a deep breath through her nose. It’s all a bit surreal: watching a man settle his daughter with a nursery rhyme while staring daggers at his long-lost father.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (rhyming/glaring) Keep it in, long as you can go, then let it out, in one... big... blow. Hope lets out her breath, a bit settled.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Samantha) Hi Honey.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Hi Baby.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (to Danny) Could I speak to you outside for a second?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Of course. Danny stands, offers his hand to Samantha.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I have, then I am truly very sorry to have missed out on you.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: (formal) Thank you for the bagels. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (smiling) Okay. Tom guides his daughter towards Danny.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hope, say goodbye to Mr. Collins.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: Goodbye to Mr. Collins.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Mr. Collins, say goodbye to Hope. Danny kneels down, takes a knowing last look at his granddaughter.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (sad smile) Goodbye to Hope. He stands, follows Tom out the door. 4l EXT. TOM AND SAMANTHA'S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS 4l Tom closes the door behind them. They stare at each other for a long beat. A really long beat. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You’re so tall.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (calmly) I’m sorry. What exactly do you want?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I just--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Are you sick? Is that why you’re here? Are you dying?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No. I’m not sick. Danny takes a deep breath, contemplating. Then:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have every right to be angry-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4l

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’m not angry, I’m really not. I’m a little confused, and strangely not interested. So if you have anything to ask me, go ahead, because this will be the last time we see each other. Danny NODS.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What do you do for a liv--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I work construction. Local residential. Not my dream job but it’s steady and Princeton wasn’t exactly in the cards. What else?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Your mom--—

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Died of cancer ten years ago. Never married, never spoke about you except to say it was a wild thing she did when she was twenty- three and got drunk backstage after a concert. I use her last name. Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You're clearly very angry.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’m not angry, I don’t care enough to be angry. I’m thinking about what I’m going to tell my daughter about you, and I’m thinking that I have to be back at work in twenty minutes. Are we done?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I’ve sent you checks.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Ripped them up. Okay? Nice to meet you, have a good life. Tom heads back inside. One last question stops him.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Are you happy?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Am I happy? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Do you have a happy life? Tom turns around. He finally slows down a little.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I hate my boss. Mets break my heart every year. But I have the best wife in the history of wives. An amazing little girl. I wish I could do more for her. I'd do anything for that. But yes. If it makes you sleep better, I’m happy. Oh, and fuck you, you selfish prick. I am angry. Tom ENTERS the house, slams the door behind him. Danny stands there for a moment, then trudges back to his car. CUE SONG: Beautiful Boy (TBD) written by John Lennon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny drives the car up toward the valet. Nicky waits:

dialogues.speaker: NICKY
dialogues.text: You were right! Jamie talked to me today. She’s never talked to me before!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That's good, Kid. That’s real good. He trudges away, inside the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny walks in, passing Jamie at the counter.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Hey, Mr. Collins!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Jamie, how ya doing? Jamie is about to respond, but Danny doesn’t wait for a reply. Jamie watches him go, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny rests his head on the hotel bar, cheek to bar. He’s been here a while. His eyes are closed. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mary steps into frame.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Mr. Collins, how we doing tonight? Danny doesn’t move, doesn’t open his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Peachy, thanks for asking.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That’s good. Real glad to hear that. Neither of them moves. Danny just lies there. Mary just stands there. After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Collins?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (head still down) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Wonder if you could help me with something? When a famous musician starts getting fall-down drunk at a hotel bar, and you’re the Manager of that hotel, is there a protocol on how to handle the situation? We’ve had a shortage of famous fall-down drunk musicians here lately and I'ma bit out of my depth. Danny finally opens his eyes, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I had a bad day.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Okay. He points at his glass.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That's just water.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes, but that’s because the ice melted. Danny nods. He suddenly looks very vulnerable. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Please don’t be mean to me. I really did have a bad day. She nods, SIGHS.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I had a bad day, too. She sits down next to Danny, three seats away. Danny looks over at her. She’s staring into space.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Can I buy you a drink? Mary looks at Danny, blankly. Danny presses on.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wine spritzer? Bay Breeze? Something froz-- Mary WHISTLES.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Josh? Tequila, rocks, something afiejo. Splash of soda.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Right away, Boss. Danny looks at Mary, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You’re not the only rock star in this hotel.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Apparently not. Danny takes in Mary. She’s back looking off into space. These are two very lost souls.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why’d you have a bad day?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh, because I work with a bunch of well-meaning but remarkably dim twenty-somethings who are just passing time until they go back to school. And one of them screwed up the computer system and it took me half the day to reprogram every reservation manually. Her drink is delivered, she takes a sip. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You? Danny takes a sip, bracing himself. Then:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I tracked down my grown son who I’d never met before. Met him, his wife, my granddaughter. Then he told me, quite emphatically, to fuck off and die. She processes this, then:

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: EVERY reservation, each one had to be reprogrammed manually. I hope I made that clear. Danny LAUGHS. Mary leans forward, serious.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a question?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Not if it’s about why I’ve never met my son until today.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Shit. That was my question. They sit there for a long beat, then, turn back to the bar, and sip their drinks in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They’re still just sitting there, sipping. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: We've lost our patter. Mary NODS, sips. After a long beat...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I saw you in concert once. About five years ago.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: My husb-- (correcting) My ex was a fan. He loved it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: And you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I appreciated your... zeal.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (“ouch”) Shit.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: “Zeal’s” not awful.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: “Zeal's” not great. A beat. Then Danny LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Zeal’s not awful, zeal’s not great.” I’m telling you, Mary, this is some kind of patter we have! We should take this on the road, we could be the new Nichols and May. She shrugs, takes a sip. A long beat of silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: May and Nichols. Danny looks up.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd want top billing. Danny smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick them up, many minutes (and many drinks) later. Danny now stands near Mary, who sits facing him (back to bar).

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: --. and then he writes, “What do you think about that, Danny Collins?”

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (repeating, laughing) John Lennon writes, “What do you think about that, Danny Collins!?” (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yes. (as if answering) I don’t know, John. I think you should have sent the letter to my house so I could have avoided living a bullshit life for the past forty years, that’s what I think. Mary explodes in laughter.

dialogues.speaker: LATER THAT NIGHT 47
dialogues.text: As Mary reveals herself a little in front of a fireplace inside the bar:

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: She’s eighteen now. Rick and I split last year. Yeah, most parents try and wait till the kids leave for college but we tried to do it at the time when it would screw her up most.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Did it work?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. She’s a complete mess. Hates both of us. But guess what?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What? Mary leans in, whispers conspiratorially:

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: She hates him more.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Perfect! Mary suddenly becomes emotional and vulnerable:

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Okay I don’t like joking about this anymore. I’m a good mother, I swear.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (whoa) No, I know. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I was just trying to be funny.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I know!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (completely gone) We did split up at the worst time possible but I don’t think she hates me. Oh, maybe she does. I don’t want any more tequila! She’s crying now, but also laughing. It’s incredibly appealing.

dialogues.speaker: LATER THAT NIGHT 48
dialogues.text: A quieter moment:

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I went on Match.com last week.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How was that?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I started filling out a profile. Divorced. Grown daughter. Hotel Manager. I started crying. I started crying from my own profile. (then) Rick will find some fun young thing. My daughter will go off to college next year. (then) I’m going to be alone for the rest of my life.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Not if you marry me.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes, well, I’1l keep that in my hip pocket, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Hey, I’m great at being married. Done it three times. (then) My second wife was actually one of the stars of Gilligan's Island. Mary looks up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Ginger? He shakes his head “no.” Suddenly, Mary gets it.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mary Ann! He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Holy shit! You were married to Mary Ann!? That’s insane!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny sits at the piano, looks at his hotel stationary pad. Mary, meanwhile, is looking at the LETTER FROM LENNON.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You better have something to play me. Because if this was just a lame attempt to get me to your room-—

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I have something to play you.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (re: letter) This is truly unreal. She shakes her head, puts the letter down. Danny settles. He’s nervous.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Okay, so, I haven’t written anything in a long time and--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Nothing to write about, I guess. And I wasn’t a great pianist to begin with so--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Enough stalling, Collins. Play it. Danny cracks his neck, then: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He starts playing. He’s playing the same MELODY he started back in the fancy studio of his mansion, before he'd received Lennon’s letter. But now it has words. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Danny starts to sing... the music is simple, the melody and lyrics wrenching.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It’s spring in my mind/But the autumn leaves they fall/As I’m walking by/I collect them all... Danny stops, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Keep going, keep going!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That’s as far as I got. Mary looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Honestly, this kind of was just a lame attempt to get you to my room.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. Mary shakes her head, stands.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Come on! Stay! I’m an old man with ten scotches in him. The odds of anything risqué happening here are very, very slim.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (with a smile) Goodnight, Danny.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (giving up) Goodnight, Mary. She stops at the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: The song’s beautiful, Danny. A little short, but it’s going to be beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Thank you. She EXITS the room, stops in the HALLWAY. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And hey, about what we talked about? You shouldn’t give up. 52A. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I agree. (then, immediately) Mary, will you have dinner with me tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Not that. Your son. Danny smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Okay. (then) But don’t give up on dinner either.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (immediately) Mary, will you have dinner with-- But the door closes before he can finish.

dialogues.speaker: ON DANNY
dialogues.text: Completely smitten... and maybe even a little inspired. 49

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOTEL GUESTS (and a lot of DENTISTS) are crammed around the GLASS DOOR, looking inside... INT. WOODCLIFF LAKE HILTON BUSINESS CENTER —- CONTINUOUS Where national icon Danny Collins sits at a COMPUTER wearing only a HOTEL ROBE and SLIPPERS. He has PAPERS scattered around him, everywhere. - He takes notes. - He sends faxes. - He makes calls. - In between he behaves as if he’s Eloise at the Plaza: LINE COOK brings in a plate from the BREAKFAST BUFFET. NEWSPAPER is delivered. COFFEE refills are served. A TAILOR measures him for a new suit jacket. 50 51

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: - We hear and see bits and pieces of everything: Danny explaining who he is over the phone. Danny giving a credit card number. Danny asking how quickly whatever he’s planning can happen.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE BUSINESS CENTER
dialogues.text: Spectators watch. Jamie approaches Nicky from behind (he doesn’t see her).

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: What’s he doing?

dialogues.speaker: NICKY
dialogues.text: He’s bitch slappin’ the business center is what he’s-- (then, seeing her) Oh, hey. Mary pushes through the spectators to see what’s going on. She sees Danny pacing around inside, a man possessed. She smiles, doesn’t interrupt. EXT. TOM AND SAMANTHA’S HOUSE - NEXT DAY 52 A quiet morning in the neighborhood. THE SAME SUBURBAN DAD now waters his lawn next door. DANNY'S GIANT TOUR BUS pulls up to the curb, catching the dad’s attention. It dwarfs the entire street, takes out branches at it comes to a stop. And out steps Danny Collins, wearing one of his finest get-ups. Danny walks towards his son’s front door. As he passes, he NODS to the neighbor.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Mornin’.

dialogues.speaker: SUBURBAN DAD
dialogues.text: (stunned) Hi. Danny RINGS the bell (he forgot it doesn’t work), then knocks per usual. The door opens. It’s Samantha:

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: (re: Danny) Oh fuck me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Language, Dear. 54A. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hope runs to the door, sees Danny.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: WE DON’T WANT YOUR MUSIC! Danny bends down, confused.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You don’t want my music? Samantha explains, pointedly:

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Tom explained to Hope the other day how you’re a musician and how some musicians go door to door to sell their music.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Ohhh. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: (still explaining) But we weren’t interested in buying any music. Much the same way some people aren’t interested in buying Girl Scout cookies. Doesn't mean we’re rude, just that we weren’t interested in buying any music.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No, I get it. Possibly more complicated an explanation than required for a seven year old, but okay. Hope spots the bus.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: Mommy look, Mommy look, do you see this?

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: (to Danny) Just out running some errands? Hope runs for it.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hope!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (calling out) Jimmy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A DRIVER (Jimmy) gets out. He opens a door for Hope, lets her in.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She’s fine, he’s got her. Tom arrives at the door, sees Danny.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (re: Danny’s presence) Are you fucking kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh good, we’re all here.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You have a hell of a nerve--

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Have you heard of the New Compass School, in Manhattan? Tom stops.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It's one of the most progressive private schools in the country. It uses... hold on: He pulls a piece of paper out of his pocket, reads:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “A multimodal approach toward treating children with learning issues, particularly ADHD.” (then) I pulled some strings. You have an interview in two hours. Hope pops out of the bus.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: It has a SHOWER!!! And she’s back inside. Tom turns back toward Danny.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Do you really think that we haven't looked into every school-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well you haven’t looked into this one.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: And how exactly do you know that? 56A. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (quietly) Because you can’t afford it. Tom steps forward, he’s had enough.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You know what--

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: (sharply) Tom. Tom goes quiet, then:

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Stephen, would you mind your fucking business please. Behind them, their nosy LANDSCAPING NEIGHBOR slips out of frame. Samantha motions towards Danny to continue. Danny takes the opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: People wait two years to get an interview. You have one in two hours. Samantha looks at Tom. Tom says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just give me one day to do something good for you. Then I’m gone forever. You'll still go to heaven ‘cause you’re so damn tolerant, and I’1l still go to hell because you can’t buy redemption. Everyone wins. Tom looks at Samantha. She clearly wants this. He shakes his head. There’s no stopping this train.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you guys want to bring any friends, there’s room. INT. TOUR BUS —- LATER A53 The THREE ADULTS awkwardly sit in the enormous bus as Hope runs around like a maniac.  53 57A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like many top private schools in Manhattan, it’s a mansion converted into a school. It looks like a place superheroes in an X-Men prequel should attend. The TOUR BUS sits outside.  54 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family stands in the middle of the school, staring. It's awe-inspiring.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: This is a school?

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: I’m not sure, Baby. A MAN (40's) ENTERS in workout clothes. This is the HEADMASTER, RYAN KURTZ. He’s reading from a CLIPBOARD.

dialogues.speaker: KURTZ
dialogues.text: Sorry to keep you waiting. And sorry I’m dressed like Jack LaLanne, I’m elastic-only on the weekends. I’m Dr. Kurtz, the headmaster here--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Tom Donn--

dialogues.speaker: KURTZ
dialogues.text: (re: Danny) Holy cow, you really are Danny Collins! Kurtz beelines for Danny. Tom continues introducing himself, even though Kurtz is no longer listening.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (to no one) --Tom Donnelly, my wife, Samantha, our daughter, Hope, my balls are in my wife’s purse, if you’re lucky you can meet them later. Samantha smiles, smacks him. Danny shakes Kurtz’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: KURTZ
dialogues.text: Wow, seeing you in person is way different than talking to you on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Good to meet you, Doc. Kurtz turns to Tom.

dialogues.speaker: KURTZ
dialogues.text: And you must be Hope. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (not that amused) Tom. Kurtz feigns confusion, turns toward Samantha.
