dialogues.speaker: KURTZ
dialogues.text: Then... you must be Hope.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Samantha.

dialogues.speaker: KURTZ
dialogues.text: Then who’s Hope? Hope, of course, finds this routine hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: I’m Hope! I’m Hope! Over here, that’s me, I’m Hope--

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Easy, Baby. Kurtz smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KURTZ
dialogues.text: Let me show you guys around. We're only half speed during our summer camp programs but you can still get a sense of the place. They follow him off. Danny holds still, unsure what to do.

dialogues.speaker: KURTZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: C'mon, you. You started all this. Danny hesitates, looks toward Tom. Tom, exasperated, throws up his hands in defeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kurtz leads them through the unbelievable facilities... technology-filled classrooms and a college level gymnasium catch the eye. Hope runs ahead, excited.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hope!

dialogues.speaker: KURTZ
dialogues.text: She’s fine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Samantha keeps her eye on Hope as she talks to Kurtz (who reads Hope’s paperwork as he walks).

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: When first grade started, she really started having trouble.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We've had her working with a private tutor once a week and I do exercises with her every night. She has a really hard time focusing, retaining information--

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (interrupting) It’s been a real struggle. Tom looks at Danny, shocked by his chutzpah. Kurtz lowers the clipboard, looks at Samantha and Tom.

dialogues.speaker: KURTZ
dialogues.text: Most schools try to train children like Hope to fit into their systems. We prefer to tailor a program to fit the child's needs. (to Danny) We call that our IEP.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: And that’s--?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Individualized Educational Program, right? IEP? They all look over at Danny, glasses on, studiously reading notes from his stationary pad.

dialogues.speaker: KURTZ
dialogues.text: You’ve done your homework, Mr. Collins. Kurtz leads Samantha into the next room. We hang on Danny who smiles, proud of himself.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You having fun?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Little bit of fun, yes. I’m very excited. Danny walks past Tom. Tom SIGHS, follows after... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PAN off a line of children’s SHOES until we land on a final pair: those belonging to Hope. She is mesmerized watching a ROOMFUL of ballet students, dancing in unison. He parents are watching her.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: And so this whole place is just an elementary school?

dialogues.speaker: KURTZ
dialogues.text: (confused) Elementary and middle. We’d carry Hope until 8th grade, then we’d place her in--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I’m sorry. We live over an hour outside the city. How would she even--

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She’1ll have a driver. Every day, to and from school. Everything will be taken care of, through college. It will be in writing.

dialogues.speaker: KURTZ
dialogues.text: A more formal interview is required, obviously. But considering Mr. Collins’ generous donation and what I see in Hope’s records... I suspect the interview will go well. (then) I don’t usually come in ona Saturday, if you catch my drift. He smiles at Danny, turns back to Tom and Samantha.

dialogues.speaker: KURTZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have a lot to discuss. But trust me: you want this. This can change the course of Hope’s life. (then) You’ve got a good grandpa here. If things could possibly get more complicated, they just did. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KURTZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’‘1l give you all a minute. He EXITS. The family is left alone. A beat, then Danny CLAPS. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Okay, so that concludes the educational portion of the day, now for the fun stuff--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, what are you talking abo--

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I asked for a day, Tom--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: But-—

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: --and you agreed to give me a day. Samantha, he did agree to give me a day, didn’t he?

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: I don’t know if “agreed” is the right word--

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Samantha.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: He agreed to give you a day. Danny smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well last I checked - day ain’t over yet. Tom and Samantha share a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TOUR BUS pulls to a stop in front. INT. TOUR BUS —- CONTINUOUS 63 We PAN through the back of the bus, now FILLED TO THE BRIM with bags from Toys R Us. On the van’s couch, Hope is asleep on Tom’s lap. She clutches MULTIPLE TOYS in her arms, as well as the remnants of something that was formerly ice cream. She's clearly had the day of her life. Samantha opens the door to the bus, steps out.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Here, I’1l take her.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: I’m carrying one of your kids already, what’s another? Tom smiles. She takes Hope, turns to Danny.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Um, SO... Her eyes well up.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to say something but I’m afraid I’m going to be too nice. Danny smiles, takes her off the hook.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Samantha.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Just... thank you. I think. Yes, definitely. Thank you. She awkwardly EXITS, carrying Hope (and some toys) with her.

dialogues.speaker: ON DANNY AND TOM
dialogues.text: Alone. Father and son, facing off. No one speaks. It’s a Mexican standoff. Finally - surprisingly - it is Tom that makes the first move. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Silence. 64. 63

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (serious) You are a ridiculous man. This hangs there.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have spent my entire life trying to become the kind of man you aren’t. I am exhausted. You have no idea how exhausting that has been. Danny thinks, explains: He pauses. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: When I met your mother... I was strung out, on God knows what. When I found out, I tried to send her money. She refused it. Over the years, I always wanted to find you, but...

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My life was extreme. The drugs. Women. Travel. I didn’t think much of myself. I thought you were better off with a normal life. And then, by the time I realized... I don’t know. I don’t know how I allowed it to go this long. Tom finally leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What you did today - your slate is clean with me. But that’s as far as this goes.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I want to be a part of your life.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No. I can’t handle that right now.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I can’t just walk away from this.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Well, you’re going to have to because it’s just not a good time-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Not a good time, what does that mean, not a good time--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’m sick. It comes out quickly, strongly, and unintentionally. The car goes silent.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit. Danny is lost.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about? What do you mean you’re sick? Tom shakes his head. He doesn’t want to do this. Finally, he gives in.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s what Mom died... (beat, then) It’s in the blood. It’s pretty bad. Danny looks stunned. A long, silent beat as he processes. Then:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Are you fucking kidding me!? Tom looks up, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just met you! I mean, you’ve got to be fucking kidding me! This hangs there, awkwardly. Danny takes a breath, regroups.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, obviously that was not a great reaction. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No, don’t be silly! I’m the one who should be sorry. After all: you’re Danny Collins! What business do I have getting in the way of your happy ending? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Tom-—

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Tell me: how did this all go in the little movie you have playing in your head? You show up out of nowhere, fix my kid’s life, and we hold hands and cry as the music swells? Was that it?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (reaching for him) I didn’t mean to--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Don’t you fucking touch me. You want a taste of the real world? You want “normal”? Well here it is, Superstar: I’ve got a two hundred thousand dollar mortgage, a pregnant wife, and oh yeah, a rare form of Leukemia that’s probably gonna kill me. Welcome home, Daddy, see what you’ve missed? Danny's head is spinning.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t need you to say anything, I need you to leave. I have to go inside before Sam asks me what we were talking about--

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Wait, wait, wait, hold on... she doesn’t know? Tom says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you insane?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I got a great doc in the city. Three weeks of this targeted therapy thing. It’s like a chemo but I don’t lose my hair or anything. They can tell within a month if I’ve responded at all. If I do, maybe I have a chance. If not, it happens quick. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Danny shakes his head, trying to process this. 66A. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Samantha--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Is six months into a rough pregnancy. After the baby, then I tell her. He stops, retaining his calm. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m going to work a job in Delaware for three weeks. That’s all she knows.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You’1ll need help. Have you told anyone? A friend?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: She’s my friend. (then) You're actually the only person who knows.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You’re telling me. They sit there with that for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, I’1l be there then.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Be where?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: There. Wherever you need me.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t need you.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well you need someone, Tom and if you think you don’t you have your head up your ass. And, however it happened, it appears I’m what you've got at the moment. So I’m going to help you with this, and it’s not open for discussion. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But-—

dialogues.speaker: 67A.
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It’s not open for discussion, Tom. It's authoritative. Fatherly. Tom stares at Danny blankly, suddenly confused by all the dynamics at play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom stands outside the bus (surrounded by bags of toys). For the first time since we’ve met him, he looks like a lost little boy. Tom watches the bus drive away. It takes out two tree branches.

dialogues.speaker: BACK INSIDE THE BUS 64
dialogues.text: Now in the clear, Danny drops the performance. He slumps against his seat, overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny walks into the lobby. Mary sees him, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How'd it go? Danny doesn’t even break stride.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah... it was just... yeah. Yeah. Mary dovetails in behind him as he walks.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Hey, c’mon! Family can be messy sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That is true. That is definitely true in this case. He pushes a button on the elevator door.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Danny! You’re meeting your grown son for the first time. You didn’t think it was going to be easy, did you? Danny LAUGHS a little. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I thought it was gonna be fucking easier than this. The elevator door opens, Danny gets in. He’s almost dazed.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Every part of me wants to just get completely soused with you right now. But I think I’m going to just go upstairs instead. That’s good, right? Mary NODS.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Write. She pulls a Hilton pen out of her jacket pocket, hands it to him. Danny looks at her. Smiles a little. The elevator door closes.  66 67 68 69. INT. DANNY’S HOTEL ROOM - LATER (NIGHT) 66 Danny sits at the piano, looking at the LETTER FROM LENNON. Next to him he has his cheap pad and pen. We can see that he’s written down LYRICS. A lot of lyrics. He begins to play the song we’ve heard him start twice. But this time, he plays it all the way through. The SONG covers a...

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (singing) It’s Spring in my Mind/But the Autumn leaves, they fall... We PAN to the lyric sheet and read (as we hear): DANNY (0.S) (CONT’D) (singing) As I’m walking by/I collect them all... On “collect them all” we head to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom leaves his site, signing off for the day. Danny sits out front, in his car. Tom spots the Mercedes immediately (hard not to spot at the construction site). Danny waves him toward the car. Tom shakes his head, puts down his TOOLS, and gets in the car without a word. We hang on the toolkit before heading to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A different type of toolkit - medical gear. A DOCTOR gives Tom an IV. Danny stands by his side. We see that Danny’s Hilton “lyric” pad has become a pad filled with medical terms: words like “Cladribine” and “Lymphocytic” and “run down” and “prone to infection” now mingle with lyrics about “spring” and “fall.” (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR SILVERMAN
dialogues.text: Okay, Mr. Donnelly, the next few weeks aren’t going to be pleasant. You ready for this? Tom NODS. Danny watches, concerned. As the nurses go to work on Tom, we RISE UP...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STILL RISING, ON A NYC STREET... revealing a boutique hotel. Expensive looking. We watch from across the street as our familiar PIANO MOVERS (and Van) once more try to navigate a piano into a (new) hotel.  70 71 72

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THAT PIANO as Danny orchestrates the move of the instrument into a hotel room (a bigger room, of course, but needless to say - still a challenge). Tom lies in a bed in the sleeping area of the suite.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I got the adjoining room but the piano won’t fit. This okay? Tom shakes his head and waves it in, giving up. Danny walks past camera and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across a familiar lawn. He avoids the broken doorbell and just KNOCKS. Samantha OPENS the door. She's surprised to see him and, clearly, unsure what to do. Danny holds up his recurrent peace offering: A BAG OF BAGELS. Samantha hesitates, then... lets him inside. INT. DANNY’S HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT 72 We go back to Danny in his room, now playing the CHORUS OF HIS SONG. PULL BACK to reveal that Mary now sits in the room with him, listening PULL BACK FURTHER to reveal: Danny's CELL PHONE, VIBRATING on the nightstand next to the Lennon letter. It’s “FRANK.” It goes to VOICE-MAIL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank hangs up the phone, concerned. Looks at a photo of he and Danny on his desk. From the photo of Danny to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REAL-LIFE DANNY, as he tentatively hands NICKY ERNST the keys to his MERCEDES and watches JAMIE hop in the front seat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Nicky gives Danny a thumbs up, and TAKES OFF. Way too fast. Danny steps back. Mary stands there. She looks at him, smiles, and MOUTHS the words:

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You're fucking crazy. INT. TOM’S HOTEL ROOM - EARLY EVENING 74 Tom rests on a couch, recuperating. Danny sits adjacent. They watch JEOPARDY together, in silence. Danny looks at Tom, notices something. He gets up, brings him some water, feels his forehead. Tom does what he can to resist, but Danny is determined and wins out. Danny motions to some SOUP (uneaten) on the table.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I got you chicken noodle soup.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t like chicken noodle soup. Silence. From one “table” we head to... INT. TOM AND SAMANTHA’S HOUSE - AFTERNOON 75 Another. Danny sits at the kitchen table with Hope, DRAWING PICTURES with her. One of her pictures is a drawing of HER FAMILY. She’s included “Gran Pa.” Samantha cooks in the background, watching. She smiles. We PUSH IN on the “Daddy” in Hope’s picture while it leads us to...

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 76
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)
(CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom. Treatment completed, he gets final instructions from Doctor Silverman. As the Doctor talks, Danny writes everything down on his STATIONARY PAD.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR SILVERMAN
dialogues.text: Okay, Tom, so three weeks from today, we’ll look at results together, hope for the best. They SHAKE, say their GOODBYES. INT. DANNY’S HOTEL ROOM - EVENING 79 Where Danny finishes the FINAL VERSE of the song, the lyric sheet now completely COVERED by lyrics and cancer terminology. Danny looks across the room at Mary, nervously. Mary CLAPS, steps forward. END MONTAGE. INT. TOM’S HOTEL ROOM - EVENING A80 Tom and Danny sit in front of the TV in silence. The uneaten soup sits in front of Tom. Danny stares at it. Finally, he can take it no more.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You just don’t like chicken noodle soup? Just unilaterally don’t like it?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How the fuck can you not like chicken noodle soup?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t like noodles, okay!? They get soggy and it makes me think of worms. (then, admitting) (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My uncle took me fishing once and freaked me out about worms.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How did he--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: He ripped one in half with his hands and then ate half the worm to fuck with me. And now when I see noodles I think of my big fat slob of an uncle eating half of a bloody fucking worm, okay? (then, meekly) I like tomato soup. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: So you just never eat chicken noodle soup?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Would you get the hell out of my room please? Danny storms out.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (enraged) Doesn't like chicken noodle soup. What kind of person doesn’t like-- The door SLAMS. Tom shakes his head. INT. TOM’S HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT B80 Tom lies in bed, reading. He’s finally got some peace, quiet, and alone time. His eyes lock on... Danny’s piano. Sitting in the corner of the room. Tom stands, goes over to it. Touches a key. Then another. He slowly begins figuring out the basic chords of Danny’s recent song. It takes him a moment to self-correct but soon... he’s playing it. Quietly humming the melody. He smiles, slowly becoming comfortable with the song. And just then...

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I got you tomato soup. Tom jolts. Stops. Stands. Danny stands at the door, with TAKEOUT FOOD, watching. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Silence. It’s a str this is di 74B.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you always been able to play by ear?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Started for me around eight years old. My mother would sing, I could play the chords. You? ange thing to not be able to admit, but clearly fficult for Tom.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I can just do it, you know? It’s not like I’m Mozart or anything but--

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You were born with it. Got your mother’s looks, but you got that from me, I guess. Danny walks over to the piano. Tom SIGHS, him.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t want to--

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh for Christ sake, Tom, sit down. There are no movies left to rent and you’re two keys off. sits. Danny puts the food down, sits next to

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here. On the bridge you should be at E, not Cc.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (standing) I don’t know what any of that means. Danny catches his arm, stopping him.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well then let me teach you, you petulant little fucker. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: B80 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And as Danny begins to teach his son to play piano we continue the song through...  c80 75. INT. DANNY’S HOTEL ROOM - DAY c80 Danny sits at the piano, writing feverishly. There's a KNOCK at the door.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Come in! It’s un-bolt-y-thing’d. The door opens, it’s Mary. She holds up a piece of PAPER.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Got your note.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Talk to me. What’d you think? Because I’m thinking of changing the whole verse. Just a complete overhaul, lyrically. Mary reads from the paper.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Pictures from my life/As I’m walking down the hall/As I am walking by/I collect them all. Danny claps.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: So!? What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You're aware I have no basis in musical knowledge or theory?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But you still want my opinion?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: As someone with no basis in musical knowledge or theory... I kind of liked it better how it was. With the leaves. Danny looks up.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: c80 75A. CONTINUED: c80

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Danny throws down his pen, changes tone.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, me too, honestly Mary: I was really just trying to get you to my room again. (then) So can I take you to dinner now?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Play it in concert, then you can take me to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You are such a dinner tease. There’s a KNOCK at the door. Danny goes to answer.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I am not a dinner tease.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You are a huge dinner tease. Danny answers the door. Frank stands there. He does not look happy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’ve been calling.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Frank!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: This is my second time in New Jersey in two months. I’m not happy about it, Danny.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Sorry, sorry, I owed you a call, you know how I get when I’m writing. He taps Frank’s cheek.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at this face! Is this a face I love or what? Great to see you, Frank! Sorry again, busy few weeks. Frank looks inside, sees Mary. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C80 CONTINUED: (2) c80

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Apparently. (then) May I? Danny motions for Frank to come in. Danny makes introductions.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Mary, my manager and best friend, Frank Grubman. Frank, this is Mary. She is my new girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (surprised) Really? Mary shakes her head no. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: c80 76. CONTINUED: (3) c80

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well, I’m hopeful. At some point, obviously, she’ll have dinner with me. (to Frank) Huge dinner tease.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I am not.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She keeps moving the goalposts for dinner. Mary LAUGHS. Frank watches, perplexed. What’s with all the cutesy? Where the hell has his pal Danny gone?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Mary, would you mind if I hada word with Danny in private?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, of course. Mary takes her leave.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Dinner tonight?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You're ridiculous. GIGGLING, Mary closes the door. Danny looks at Frank, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Right?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (admitting) She’s lovely.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: And age appropriate.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Baby steps. Frank smiles, sits. Danny sits next to him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: We need to talk. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: We do. I have a lot to tell you about, Pal--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Danny, unfortunately I’ve got the Manager hat back on right now. Danny nods. Something’s clearly wrong. He changes tone, serious.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What’s up? Frank thinks. How to say this?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Do you remember a few years ago we were watching that thing on ESPN about Mike Tyson? And they were saying how even though he’d made like twenty million a fight, he’d blown it all, and now he could barely afford to feed the pigeons on his roof? Danny processes this. Then, childlike, asks:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I’m Mike Tyson?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Well, not quite, but... I’ve been going over things with Bill and you’re not quite where you think you are. Danny nods, staying calm.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Okay. Where am I?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You're a little bit ahead, once we sell properties. But just a little. Danny lets this sink in.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. How?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Lot of things. We shouldn’t have sold your publishing rights so early. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All the properties, the housing markets have collapsed. The private planes, your lifestyle, the Madoff thing absolutely killed you, as you know. You’re not bankrupt or anything, but you need to understand how serious this is.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Okay, I understand. (then) What do I do?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: One of two things: you start living like a normal human - buy a Prius, fly Continental, that kind of shit... or you go back on tour. This last tour was my retirement plan for you. We had a big piece: merchandise, concessions--

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No, I know. They sit in silence for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve been writing, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Danny-—

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It's good. I’m telling you, Mary thinks it’s really good.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The Woodcliff Lake Hotel manager? Oh, okay. Well now I feel better.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Careful. Frank eases up.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just book me a gig.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: A “gig?”

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Something local. Not an arena. Like what Springsteen would do if he was just popping in somewhere. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: c80 80 79. CONTINUED: (6) c80

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: “Like what Springsteen would do?” Danny, do you even hear yourself.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I’m telling you: the new stuff will play. Then we tour. And the bonus is that I won’t have to feel like killing myself every night. Frank SIGHS, shakes his head. Stands.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Okay. Frank stops at the door, turns.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just don't buy any pigeons. Frank EXITS. Danny thinks for a beat, then he sits back at his PIANO and continues working... a man possessed. PRE-LAP: a spoon clinks on glass, signaling a toast.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: If I could have your attention please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, Samantha, Hope, and Danny sit on lawn chairs at a makeshift inflatable pool. Samantha is even more pregnant now... she’s huge. Danny has allowed Hope (in pool) to tap a spoon on his COFFEE MUG. He has an announcement.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: So I’m playing a gig at a bar Friday night.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (amused) A "gig"?

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: What's a gig?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It's where I sing in front of people, Hon. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: I want to hear you sing.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: And I want you to hear me sing. More than anything. But only if it’s okay with your parents. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: (concerned) It’s at a bar?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Upscale bar. Cover charges, cocktail menus, a real “gig” type gig, you know?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (amused) You're playing somewhere with a “cover charge”? Are times that tough? Hold on: will you have enough room to prance?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Ha. Sam smiles. Hope giggles, not getting the joke but enjoying that her parents are.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's really more of a small music venue, like a theater. (off their looks) Seriously! There will be a sectioned-off table for you and everything. Tom and Samantha share a look, still hesitant. But Danny

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Show starts at 7:30. Done by 9:00. Late but not too late.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Can your fans even stay conscious till 9:00? Someone better warn the bar that they could have a room full of snoring old women. Honey?

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: (with a smile) I’‘1l call them, give them a heads up. is serious, ignores the teasing.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It's a big one for me. (pleading) It would help if I could see these cheeks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He squeezes Hope’s CHEEKS. She GIGGLES. Tom SHRUGS at Samantha. It’s her call.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Okay. Hope and Danny share a HIGH FIVE.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: These cheeks will be there. Everyone LAUGHS, but laughing makes Tom COUGH, loudly. Samantha goes to get him water.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: (to Danny) Do you hear this? (then, to Tom) Would you get yourself to the doctor already, Tom? Danny looks at Tom. Tom quickly looks away.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s just a little bug.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Little bug, it’s been ever since you got back. Hope, is your daddy the most stubborn man on the planet?

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: Don’t be so stubborn, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’m fine, really. Samantha feels his head.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: He insists on walking around like the living dead instead of getting antibiotics. Stubborn man.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE
dialogues.text: Stubborn man. Samantha smiles, kisses Hope’s head. Tom and Danny share a look but say nothing. Over the top of their silence we: CUE SOUND: THUMP. THUMP. THUMP.  81 82 82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ritual: Danny’s hand comes into frame, touches... THE GOLD CROSS, which drops down into his chest. But instead of opening the cross in search of drugs, now the hand lowers, touching: THE LETTER FROM LENNON. Sitting on a nearby table. A source of inspiration. We PULL BACK, revealing:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: For the first time since we’ve known him, Danny isn’t dressed like a borderline Vegas pimp. He’s wearing casual clothes. Slacks. He looks...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jesus, you look like Lee Trevino. Danny looks up, Frank stands there. Danny smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Samantha took me shopping. You ever heard of this place, “Banana Republic?” Amazing place. Frank CHUCKLES, ENTERS.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Okay: house is packed. The band’s out there and ready. Phil can step in on piano if you need him on your new one. He looks at Danny. Danny smiles, shakes his head “no.” Frank nods, continues.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your family’s up front. I saved a spot for Mary with them. Danny nods, deep breath. Then, notices: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Speak of the devil. Frank turns, following Danny’s gaze. MARY stands at the door. Frank smiles, takes his leave.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Break a leg, Kid.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Just tell me whose. The old joke. Frank winks and EXITS. We hold on Danny in the mirror as we hear...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, just go on in. He’ll be thrilled to see you. Danny looks up. Mary walks into frame (in the mirror).

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Just came to wish you luck. (beat) You nervous?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Mary, I have done this a zillion times and I’ve never been nervous. Hand to God, not once. (then) I’m nervous as hell. She nods, understanding. He snaps out of it, feigning calm.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Looks like you’re finally going to have to let me buy you dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Let’s see how you do first. Danny smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (playful) Okay, okay. Put a little more pressure on me tonight, I see what you're doing. She LAUGHS, walks to the door, stops. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She EXITS. 83A.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It's a weird thing to say, I know, considering I haven’t known you very long. But I’m very proud of you, Danny Collins. Danny takes a deep breath, stands.  83
INT. LOU’S BAR (LOUNGE) - MEANWHILE A84 Mary sits with Tom, Samantha, and Hope.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: So, how long have you known my father?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Roughly about the same amount of time as you have? Tom NODS.

dialogues.speaker: OVER ON FRANK
dialogues.text: Who sits with Nicky and Jamie. They are holding hands.

dialogues.speaker: NICKY
dialogues.text: You look really nice.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You look nice, too. FRANK grimaces at the cutesy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oh for Christ's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM BEHIND, we watch Danny make his way toward the BACKSTAGE CURTAIN. We’re once again tracking him from behind (just as at his first concert). But now, instead of a mysterious figure in a white suit, he’s just a grandpa in a golf shirt and slacks.

dialogues.speaker: ON HIS FEET
dialogues.text: No more platform shoes. Brown loafers have taken their place.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE CURTAIN
dialogues.text: He pauses, stops. He cracks his head each way, then:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yep. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He EXITS onto the stage. From behind the curtain, we hear the small crowd go APESHIT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny takes the stage, looks out. It’s a packed house.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT UP FRONT
dialogues.text: Sits his family at a table. Mary is with them. So is Frank. He smiles at them. Hope SCREAMS through the crowd, bursting with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: ON DANNY
dialogues.text: He looks toward the back of the stage: His BAND is ready, unsure what they’re supposed to do. Danny simply nods at them and heads towards:

dialogues.speaker: HIS PIANO
dialogues.text: Simple and unadorned. Center stage. Danny sits. He leans into the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming. Danny starts playing the opening of his NEW SONG. We recognize the melody instantly. As he plays...

dialogues.speaker: THE CROWD
dialogues.text: A WOMAN SCREAMS for Danny to play his MOST POPULAR SONG:

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Hey, Baby Doll!!! AN OLDER COUPLE CLAP THEIR HANDS in unison, anticipating. In fact... EVERYONE is clapping. In UNISON. These are Danny Collins fans. They know what happens first. Everything SLOWS DOWN. ANOTHER FAN screams for Danny’s most popular song. AND ANOTHER. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 86A.
dialogues.text: AT HER TABLE, Hope looks around, thrilled. She's CLAPPING with everyone. with her. Frank, too.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO DANNY
dialogues.text: Tom and Samantha LAUGH, clap (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Suddenly frozen. He just sits there, playing the same melody over and over again, watching the CHANTING CROWD. His adoring granddaughter. His son. He knows what they want from him. We watch it happen, just like that - in an instant: all progress lost. There’s too many people. He’s too old. He can’t just change it up suddenly. He knows what they want and he has to give it to them. He’s been doing it for too many years to stop now. Slowly, he stops playing. His eyes are glossy. He turns to his band, NODS. They quickly pick up their instruments.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Phil? Danny stands, as PHIL quickly scurries over behind the piano. Danny grabs his microphone and forces a smile:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gotta stand up for this puppy. He announces, sadly:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think you know this one-- The band launches into Danny’s MOST FAMOUS SONG. The crowd goes ballistic. As Danny goes through the motions, we push in CLOSER AND CLOSER on his face. He’s singing. He’s performing. He’s breaking his own heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on a black curtain. Above it there’s a BLINKING RED LIGHT. We hear the CROWD GOING NUTS. We watch as the blinking light goes off.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming everyone. Means a lot. Thank you, thank you. Danny ENTERS FRAME, safely out of sight from his adoring masses. As soon as he’s behind the curtain, he sinks. He’s a broken man. And then, to our surprise...

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Danny!? Sophie and Judd (Busywork) run over.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We heard about the gig and we came to support our Sugar Daddy. I used your credit card for the flights, hope that’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: JUDD
dialogues.text: When do you go on!? Sophie SNIFFLES, rubs her nose. Danny stares at her blankly, then:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What do you have on you?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You know what I mean. Sophie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I got it all, Baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny chugs from a bottle of SCOTCH, numbing himself as quickly as possible. Judd SMOKES in the corner. Sophie pours some COKE OUT onto A TRAY, hands it to Danny.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Here you go, Danny. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: But it’s not a tray... she’s poured a line on the FRAMED LETTER FROM LENNON. Sad, horrific, irony. Danny shakes his head, hesitates, then bends down to do it. Just then:

dialogues.speaker: HOPE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Grandpa! Danny looks up and drops the letter to the ground, as coke goes flying.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE DOOR
dialogues.text: Tom, Samantha, and Hope stand there.

dialogues.speaker: HOPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (confused) Grandpa? Samantha quickly pulls Hope back. Tom looks on, shocked. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Nice. (pointedly) Real nice, Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I didn’t--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Don’t. Don’t even bother. He turns away, then turns back, furious. He moves at Danny quickly. Grabs him. He could hit him, but he catches himself. He looks at Danny, a beaten man.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus. He turns to go. Danny calls out:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yes, keep judging me, Tom, you're great at that. When you finish - you know, being so perfect and honorable - maybe you should talk to your wife about what you did in “Delaware.” As soon as he says it he regrets it. Tom freezes. Samantha (pushing Hope out the door) stops, confused.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA
dialogues.text: Huh? Tom glares at Danny. Samantha looks at Tom, it’s too weird not to comment on.

dialogues.speaker: SAMANTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s he talking about? Tom turns to her. She looks at him, expectant. He knows it’s over.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We’ll talk at home, okay? He leads his family out the door, but not before turning back towards Danny.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you ever come near my family again... He trails off. The message is clear. Nothing left to say. And with that... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He EXITS.

dialogues.speaker: ON DANNY
dialogues.text: Completely undone. He bends down, picks up the LENNON LETTER off of the ground.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE LETTER
dialogues.text: It's cracked, smattered with cocaine. Symbolic.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO DANNY
dialogues.text: Who turns towards Sophie and Judd.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Let’s get the fuck out of here. CUE SONG: Cold Turkey (TBD) written by John Lennon. INT. DANNY’S HOTEL ROOM - NEXT MORNING 88 We hear a KEY go into a door. The door opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking through the small hotel room: The room is trashed. Bottles and cans everywhere. The LENNON LETTER lies on the floor, cracked. There’s an overturned ROOM SERVICE TABLE in the center of the room. And on the bed, Danny is sprawled out, unconscious. His shirt half unbuttoned. A BOTTLE OF BOOZE on his chest.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAMERA TURNS AROUND
dialogues.text: Revealing Mary, the source of our POV. Taking in the train wreck. Just then... SOPHIE stumbles out of the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (wasted) Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I... um... I work for the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Oh, good. We need more towels, can you do that? And some beer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes. More towels. And some beer. The conversation causes Danny to STIR. He opens his eyes, sees...

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Mary. Mary turns, walks out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary heads for the elevator. Half stumbling, half dressed, Danny runs after her.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Mary! Mary, wait! Mary turns.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She’s not... it’s not what it looks like.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What the hell happened last night, Danny? Danny looks down.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It just wasn’t right. It wasn’t the right time.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about!? You’ve been working so hard. Your whole family was there--

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I couldn’t. I just... lost my nerve. She takes him in. He’s barely making eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, you lost your dinner, too.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Mary-- The elevator door opens. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You should have played the song, Danny. You should have at least played the one fucking song. Mary GETS IN THE ELEVATOR, leaving Danny alone in the hallway.  90 91 92 92. INT. DANNY’S HOTEL ROOM - CONTINUOUS 90 Danny RE-ENTERS his room. He picks up the LENNON LETTER from the floor, looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (to letter) Fuck you, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny rolls his SUITCASE into the elevator. He's leaving. As the elevator descends, it plays THE MUZAK of Danny's most famous song. Danny NODS, knowingly. One last final body blow before he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny rolls his SUITCASE through the lobby. Jamie works behind the front desk. Danny sees her.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You take care of yourself, Jamie.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: You too, Mr. Collins.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: And be good to Nicky. He’s a good boy. Wonderful face.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Yours isn’t so bad either, Mr. Collins.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well look at that: now we're getting patter. Danny looks behind Jamie, toward the OFFICE that hides beyond the front desk. Jamie shakes her head “no.” Mary doesn’t want to see him. Danny nods, steps up to the desk, and yells out:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: FOR THE RECORD: MARY ANN’S REAL

dialogues.speaker: MISS NEVADA BEFORE SHE GOT FAMOUS
dialogues.text: AND SHE COULDN’T HOLD A FUCKING CANDLE TO YOU. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BUT NOT GIRLY. GOODBYE
dialogues.text: Danny turns and EXITS the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky pulls up the Mercedes, loads in the SUITCASE.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Nicky, it’s been a pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: NICKY
dialogues.text: The pleasure has definitely been mine, Danny. Danny reaches into his pocket to TIP Nicky. But he’s got no cash.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Shit. (then) You know what? Danny goes to his trunk, removes the suitcase, and WHISTLES for a cab (in line at the nearby stand). He hands NICKY the KEYS to the Mercedes.

dialogues.speaker: NICKY
dialogues.text: You’re kidding me. Danny smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: The second you stop appreciating it, you give it to someone else. Deal?

dialogues.speaker: NICKY
dialogues.text: Deal.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Good. Now get the hell out of here. Nicky doesn’t know what to do with himself. He BEAR HUGS Danny, gets in the car, and ZOOMS off.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Wait! (CONTINUED)
93 Mary runs out, catches up to him. They stand there.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t want the last thing I ever said to you to be mean. But I don’t want to say anything nice. So... (then) Mr. Collins: on behalf of the Woodcliff Lake Hilton, we hope you enjoyed your stay and hope you will choose to make Hilton home, wherever you travels take you. They stand there in awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I’m grabbing a cab.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I see that.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I gave Nicky my Mercedes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You're fucking crazy.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It's been said, yes. Danny turns to her. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I called Frank this morning. I’m going back on tour.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Good. Good, right?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I need the money. I have a family now. They hate my guts, but I’m told that’s just what families do.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I’ve taught you well.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I’m gonna play my new songs. At least some of them. We’1ll see what happens. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I know what will happen.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: They’1l throw tomatoes?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Onions.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Better. Danny loads his suitcase into the TAXI.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tour comes to The Garden in a few months. Maybe I could take you to dinner after the show?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (with a smile) You’re relentless. Danny gets in the taxi, lowers the window.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I left you something in the room.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You probably left me a big mess is what you left me.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Hey, you know us rock stars. Danny takes her in one last time, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Another life, huh?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You never know. Danny smiles, winks, and taps the window. He came to the Woodcliff Lake Hilton in a red Mercedes. He leaves in a yellow taxi.  94 95

INT. DANNY’S HOTEL ROOM - LATER 94 Mary ENTERS the room with TWO CLEANING LADIES. But the room... Is immaculate. Danny has cleaned it himself. On the bed, sits the LENNON LETTER. Next to it, a SECOND NOTE, from Danny: It reads: “What do you think about that, Mary Sinclair?”

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well I’1l be damned. He made a clean exit. She chuckles to herself, stands, and kicks Busywork (sprawled on the floor).

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Be out of the room by noon. And with that, Mary Sinclair EXITS. CUE SONG: Jealous Guy (TBD) written by John Lennon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny sits in his seat, waiting for liftoff. He talks on his cell.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’1l meet you guys in Pittsburgh. Frank’s setting up the other dates. Okay, talk soon. A STEWARDESS approaches.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARDESS
dialogues.text: We're ready for takeoff, Mr. Collins. Say goodbye to New Jersey. He looks out his window, speaks to himself.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Goodbye to New Jersey.  96 96A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of feet makes the familiar trek past Tom’s front yard. A finger rings the familiar doorbell. Rings again. Still broken. The hand knocks. The door opens. It’s Tom. Standing opposite him is... Frank.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus. What now? Did he send you to check on me?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The hotel didn’t know what to do with the damn piano. I thought you might want it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Frank motions to a MOVING TRUCK out front manned by FOUR LARGE MEN. Tom shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I don’t want his piano.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Well, it took six hours to move it out of the Hilton and I don’t know anyone else in New Jersey, so tough shit. (then) It's a thirty thousand dollar instrument, Tom. Sell it for all I care. A beat, then Tom nods, exhausted. Frank motions at the movers, they start opening the truck.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your health?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (shrug) Find out in a few days. Frank nods, takes a sip from his ubiquitous water bottle.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: When I was in my thirties, I started drinking. Heavily. Don’t remember how it started. Everyone was always drinking before his shows. After his shows. Long line of drunks in my family, all the usual bullshit excuses. Out of nowhere, Frank yells at the movers behind him:

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Careful, gentlemen, that’s a Steinway. It’s worth more than you are. He turns back to Tom, SHRUGS, continues.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We were on tour in the Bay Area and I fell asleep at the wheel. Almost killed myself, a few others. Got arrested. Your fa-- (then) Danny bailed me out. Five in the morning he showed up at the San Jose police station high as a fucking kite. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Drives me six hours straight to this Hollywood rehab joint... probably drove us there drunker than I'd been the night before, the dumb shit. Paid for the whole thing. Visited me every Saturday till I was dry. And once a week, for the last thirty years, I get four cases of bottled water sent to me, wherever I am in the world. Always with the same note: “Drink as many as you want on me, Danny.” Frank taps his water bottle.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Best friend I ever had your father. The man saved my life, got me stone-cold sober, and he was three sheets to the wind himself the entire time he was doing it.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’m not seeing the point here.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The point, my boy, is that he’s always been better to others than he has been to himself. What you do with that, is up to you. My waters will keep coming no matter what. Frank tips an imaginary hat, turns back to the movers.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alright, boys, let’s move that puppy so I can get the fuck out of New Jersey. Tom stands at the door, watching Frank go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom holds Hope on his lap as she BANGS away on the piano (which is wildly out of place and oversized for the cramped living room). He picks Hope up, places her on the bench by herself, and kisses her forehead. Sam watches adoringly (and WILDLY pregnant) from the couch (where she lies). Tom moves to her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He takes her hand, kisses it. He goes to pull away but she won't let him go. She has tears in her eyes. He nods at her: a solid, steadying look. He kisses her again, kisses her belly, then EXITS.

dialogues.speaker: A98
dialogues.text: We’re used to watching Danny walk toward the house. This time, we watch his son walking away from it... toward the unknown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A medical office building in NYC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom makes the long trek down the building’s hallway, stops at a door, opens it, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ENTERS the waiting room, turning a corner only to see... Danny. Sitting there. Alone. Waiting. Tom shakes his head, SIGHS. He checks in with a NURSE.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Tom Donnelly. Here for Dr. Silverman.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Just have a seat, Mr. Donnelly. Tom sits two seats away from Danny. They sit in silence for a long beat. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Was she pissed?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No, she was thrilled. It’s been a great few weeks, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It’s no excuse but it was a horrible night for me. 98 99

dialogues.speaker: A100
dialogues.text: 100 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, it was a worse one for me, I assure you. Silence. Long beat.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Why isn’t she... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: She can barely even move. Plus, whatever the news is, I want her to hear it from me. Not some doctor. A beat, then...

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Tom, I--

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Donnelly? The NURSE beckons. Tom STANDS. Danny STANDS with him. Tom SIGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom and Danny wait, on an EXAM TABLE, side by side. Danny looks at Tom’s foot. It’s TAPPING, relentlessly. They sit there for a while like this. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: If the news is bad... Tom stops, gathering himself.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Tom, c’mon--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No, listen to me. If this goes bad, Samantha, and Hope, and the baby--

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Will be taken care of. You don’t need to worry about that. Tom nods. He’s starting to cry but doing the best he can to hold it back.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Okay. Good. Thank you. A beat. Tom speaks, almost to himself:

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am not ready to leave them. I am not ready. Danny puts his hand on Tom’s knee, steadying his shaky leg. Danny takes a deep breath himself. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You know... this doctor, whenever he comes in here, he either calls you Mr. Donnelly or Tom? Ever notice that? Always one or the other. When he calls you Mr. Donnelly, it’s never good news. Next thing you know he’s shooting you with something that makes you throw up, or telling you he doesn’t like your levels. I’m serious, I’ve taken notes, he literally does it every time. (then) But when he calls you Tom, it’s always good news. Like that time he liked your white cell count, remember that? He called you Tom. So that’s what we want right now. We want him to open that door, come in here, and call you “Tom.” That’s all we want. Let’s focus on that, okay? Tom nods, takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It's going to be alright, Son. Everything will be alright.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (choking up) You promise? Danny looks at his son.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Have I ever let you down before? Tom CRACKS UP through his tears. Crying now...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You’re a ridiculous man, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I’ve been told, yes. Tom considers the man sitting next to him, then, giving in to it... he puts his hand on top of his father’s. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The camera swings behind them, slowly, till it lands on their backs (facing the door). As it swings around, Danny continues talking, soothing.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yep, he’s just gonna open that door and call you Tom. It will all be alright. Everything will be alright. We’re behind them now, father and son, touching hands in silence. And just then... The door OPENS. Their heads jolt up and we... FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: THE END
dialogues.text: But not before we hear, over black:

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR SILVERMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay, Tom, so here’s where we are...

dialogues.speaker: A NOTE TO THE READER
dialogues.text: In 1971, John Lennon read an interview in a small music magazine. The subject of the interview was a twenty-one year old musician named Steve Tilston. In the interview, Tilston admitted wondering if future wealth and fame might one day hinder his ability to write powerful songs. And so... John Lennon wrote Steve Tilston a letter. In the letter, Lennon offered Tilston advice and friendship, as well as his home phone number. Steve Tilston did not receive the letter until 2005. He was nearly sixty years old at the time.
